content.text: Label with the letter X the point on the graph where the sky-diver opens her parachute
Label with the letters Y and Z the two parts of the graph where the sky-diver falls at terminal velocity
Describe, in terms of the forces acting on the sky-diver, her motion between leaving the balloon and opening her parachute
average speed = .........
A sky-diver jumps out of a hot-air balloon, which is \(4000 \text{m}\) above the ground. At time \(= 30 \text{s}\), she opens her parachute
Fig. 1.1 is the speed-time graph of her fall
Define the moment of a force about a point
the weight \(W\) of the rod
the moment of \(W\) about the pivot
the moment of \(F\) about the pivot
the force \(F\)
Fig. 2.1 shows a uniform rod of wood suspended from a pivot
The rod is held stationary by a horizontal force \(F\) acting as shown
The mass of the rod is \(0.080 \text{kg}\)
Calculate:
The angle between the rod and the vertical is increased
State whether the force \(F\) needed to hold the rod stationary must be increased, decreased or stay the same
Explain your answer

The kinetic energy of air passing through a wind turbine every minute is \(720000 \text{J}\). The electrical output of the turbine is \(9.0 \text{A}\) at a potential difference (p.d.) of \(240 \text{V}\)
Calculate the efficiency (%) of the wind turbine
efficiency = .........%
State the name of this type of thermometer
Fig. 4.2 shows the same thermometer used to measure the temperature of liquid X
With the setup in Fig. 4.2, the voltmeter reading is \(1.7 \text{mV}\)
Calculate the temperature of liquid X measured by the thermometer
temperature = .........
Suggest an application for which this type of thermometer is more suitable than a liquid-in-glass thermometer
Fig. 4.1 shows a thermometer
The voltmeter reading is \(5.4 \text{mV}\)
Define specific latent heat
Explain the melting of a solid in terms of molecules and energy
An electrical heater is used to heat a liquid to its boiling point. Fig. 5.1 shows the apparatus
When the liquid is boiling, the heater supplies \(1.26 \text{MJ}\) of thermal energy. The mass reading shown on the balance decreases from \(3800 \text{g}\) to \(2300 \text{g}\)
Calculate the specific latent heat of vaporisation of the liquid
specific latent heat = .........
State and explain a precaution to improve the accuracy of the value of specific latent heat calculated in (b)
draw labelled lines to show
1. the amplitude of the wave
2. the wavelength of the wave
label a trough with the letter T
On Fig. 6.1:
A person vibrates one end of the string vertically to produce the wave. He makes 15 complete oscillations in 60 s
Show that the speed of the wave is \(2.0 \text{cm / s}\)
State the difference between transverse waves and longitudinal waves. Use your ideas about the direction of oscillations
transverse waves
longitudinal waves
Fig. 6.1 shows a transverse wave produced in a string
No light refracts from the fibre at points P and Q
State the name of the process that occurs at P and Q
Calculate the minimum value of angle \(i\) for there to be no refraction at point P
State and explain the use of optical fibres in medicine
The ray of light shown in Fig. 7.1 is monochromatic light from a laser
State what is meant by monochromatic light. Use one of the following quantities in your answer
**amplitude** **brightness** **frequency** **refractive index** **speed**
Fig. 7.1 shows a ray of light passing through an optical fibre
The optical fibre is made of glass that has a refractive index of 1.4
State and explain why electrical sockets and plugs used outside in a garden need to be different from those that can be used safely in a room inside a house
State and explain why fuses and circuit breakers are installed in electrical circuits connected to the mains supply
draw an arrow on each of the three plotting compasses B, C and D to show the direction of the magnetic field
label the magnetic poles of the bar magnet N and S
Fig. 9.1 shows a bar magnet and four plotting compasses A, B, C and D
On Fig. 9.1:
Describe **one** method for demagnetising a bar magnet
Draw the pattern of the magnetic field produced around the wire. Show clearly the direction of the magnetic field
The direction of the current in the wire is reversed. The magnitude of the current is unchanged
State the effect that reversing the current has on the magnetic field produced
Fig. 9.2 represents a current in a wire. The current is into the plane of the paper
A student completes the circuit and measures the current in the \(6.0 \Omega\) resistor
On Fig. 10.1, draw an ammeter symbol in one gap and straight lines to indicate wires in the other gaps to show how the student should do this.
A voltmeter is connected to measure the potential difference (p.d.) across the \(4.0 \Omega\) resistor
On Fig. 10.1, draw a voltmeter symbol connected in the correct position.
With the circuit completed, the current in the \(2.0 \Omega\) resistor is \(2.5 \text{A}\)
Calculate the current in the \(6.0 \Omega\) resistor
current = .........
Fig. 10.2 shows the same electrical circuit with an alternating current (a.c.) power supply and a wire in the gap AB

On Fig. 10.2, draw a diode symbol in one gap and a straight line to indicate a wire in the other gap so that there is a current from right to left in the \(4.0 \Omega\) resistor and an alternating current in the \(2.0 \Omega\) resistor.
Fig. 10.1 shows an incomplete electrical circuit
State two differences between nuclear fission and nuclear fusion
Explain why a source of \(\gamma\) -rays used in this way should not have a half-life shorter or longer than about 6 hours

Technetium-99 is a source of \(\gamma\) -rays often used as a radioactive tracer. It is produced from molybdenum-99 which emits \(\beta\) -particles. The symbol for technetium is Tc and the symbol for molybdenum is Mo
Complete the nuclide equation for this decay
Technetium-99 is a radioactive nuclide
State another use of radioactive nuclides in medicine
Radioactive tracers emitting \(\gamma\) -rays can be used in medicine. The half-life of the source of these \(\gamma\) -rays is 6 hours
